lines.text: You know how old mirrors are. I never made a move yet without something getting broken.
Hey, that's seven years' bad luck!
Nonsense. I broke a mirror the day I met your mother.
I'm not sure that makes your point, darling.

[to unseen presence in the woods]
She's going to stay here. Is that what you wanted?
Mom said she'd only be a minute.
Yeah, well that means ten.
Did you hurt yourself?
Oh, it's just a little cut. I thought... I thought I saw something out there in the woods.
What sort of person are you?
That's hard to say. Just average, I guess.
Are you adventurous? And kind? Are you kind?
I... try to be.
And sensitive? Do you sense things?
Boy, Mrs. Aylwood sure is creepy.
How comforting to know we're the "right sort of people."
I've seen the iciest of old ladies melted by your charm.
I think it was your daughter who did the trick.
Me?
No, dear, not you.
[to Jan]
She had a daughter about your age.
Had?
Mm, lost. Many years ago. Perhaps you reminded Mrs. Aylwood of her.
Something awful happened here. I can feel it. Something awful.
She had to. She had to push you down to get you loose from the branch. She saved your life.
Here. Hold. It won't hurt you none. They know when you try to help.
Mr. Keller I had to see you, it's about Karen Aylwood.
What about Karen Aylwood?
She needs help.
How would you know that?
I've seen her.
Where?
I'm mirrors!
Oh, mirrors. You say you see yourself as Karen?
No! It was her image. Why was she blindfolded at the chapel? I've got to find out what happened that night, it's important to me.
Why dear? It's none of your business!
Don't you see? She needs my help, she's trapped somewhere...
That's enough! I have better things to do than listen to hysterical fantasies. What happened to Karen was a tragedy that touched us all, changed us all and it's best forgotten.
Have you ever forgotten?
Clear out of here!
Mr. Keller, please!
